Owww! Fuck! Richard!

I’m sorry, I’m sorry. Richard’s hand trembles as he pulls the plunger back to for blood. There is none, so he pushes the plunger down.
Almost done. Almost done. Almost done. Done. Richard pulls out the needle; Rachel looks at her hip.
I think you hit a nerve. Still holding the syringe, Richard uses his teeth to open a SMALL FOIL ENVELOPE, causing him to slur --

Uhm shorry, honey. I did ekshactly what the nursh told me to do. He spits out the torn-off strip, removes an ALCOHOL PAD a presses it over the injection site just as TWO RESCUE DOG ENO and LAZLO, click into the room and hop up on the bed.
(pointing) Wasn’t it supposed to be more like here?
Nope. Upper outer quadrant.
Then why did it hurt like that? Nobody on the message boards said it’s supposed to hurt like that.

I don’t know, Rache. It’s a bigger needle. Maybe you have a lower pain threshold than most people. I don’t know. I’m not a doctor. Remember? Rachel watches Richard as he climbs off the bed and drops used syringe in a PLASTIC WATER BOTTLE that already conta dozen others. This new, larger one, lands with a dull CLU
Are you mad at me?

No. I’m not mad. I’m just... Whatever. I don’t know. Tired. Richard picks up something from a nearby bureau and offer it to Rachel: It’s A BAG OF FROZEN PEAS. Husband and wife regard each other for an odd moment, th Rachel takes the peas, places them on her aching ass and Richard leaves. CUT TO BLACK. UNDER BLACK, A CARD -——

A big, bright modern space with large windows. At 7:15 A. it’s already packed with (mostly white) women in their la and early 40s. Some are accompanied by husbands. Some are alone. There are several Hasidic couples. One lesbian cou Among this crowd are Rachel and Richard. SUPERIMPOSE -—

Richard does the crossword puzzle while Rachel sits with unread magazine on her lap, furtively observing her fello patients, including -- A TENSE WOMAN, dressed for work, tapping her Blackberry. Rachel’s eyes float down to the woman’s HANDSOME LEATHER PUMPS with gold buckles, then Rachel examines her own shoes: OLD SAUCONYS in dingy yellow. DING! The elevator arrives and Rachel watches as a SINGLE WOMAN steps out, wheeling a CRYOGENIC TANK. The woman scans the room for an empty seat. There are none, so she just stands there, stranded with her tank of frozen sperm With the SWOOSH of a door, a NURSE emerges and everyone looks up expectantly.
Rachel? Rachel rises, holding her coat, scarf and purse in an awkward heap as the magazine drops to the floor.

A WEDDING BAND, WATCH and NECKLACE are placed one at a ti on a Formica surface next to CELLOPHANE WRAPPED HOSPITAL GARMENTS . WIDER shows Rachel in her underwear and socks as she unsc an earring. We notice a CHAIN OF PURPLE INJECTION BRUISES above her panty line as she looks around the sterile room wondering how she ended up here.

These are your consent forms.
Richard stands at a desk as an ADMITTING NURSE presents him with various documents.

Both partners signatures are required on the second page. This is our policy regarding embryo storage. The fee schedule is on the back. You both need to initial each paragraph then sign here. She fastens the documents onto a clipboard and hands it t him. As Richard turns to go -- And this is for you. She disappears behind the desk and reappears with a PLAST BAG containing A SPECIMEN CUP. Instructions are inside. Richard takes the cup and smiles awkwardly.
There you are! Richard turns to see Rachel approaching in a HOSPITAL GOW PAPER SHOWER CAP and her locker key dangling from her wri She seems anxious.
What’s wrong?
Nothing. It’s fucking freezing in here. Richard puts an arm around her and rubs her shoulders.
Shhh. Relax. Don’t obsess.
I’m not obsessing. I’m cold. He guides her into --
-- and they sit down among several other couples.
(handing her the clipboard) You need to sign these. As Rachel begins examining the papers, she mumbles to her
Oh, my god. What are we doing? Are we really doing this? Are we insane?
We’re not insane. We’re normal. Richard folds back the papers and points out a signature
(signing) This is not normal. This is the opposite of normal. I’m not sure if it’s even ethical. Remember what Marty said? “Having a baby is an immoral act.”
Marty’s an idiot.
“Overpopulation, climate change... Richard notices a nearby couple giving them looks. ...the rise of neo-fascism --”
Did you take your Valium?
Yes. Why?
Ms. Biegler? Rachel turns to see a nurse standing a few feet away. Rac signals that she’ll be right there, then turns back to Ri
Okay, I guess we’re doing this.
Don’t be scared, okay? You're gonna do great. All we need is one good egg, right?  Moved by her husband's optimism, Rachel smiles and nods.
You, too honey. Don’t be scared. You’re gonna do great. Richard smiles feebly and raises his specimen cup. Rachel chortles quietly. I love you.
I love you, too. They kiss. As Richard watches his wife being led off to surgery, we hear the incongruent SOUND of GRUNTING and MOANING.

A NAKED WOMAN ON ALL FOURS with giant fake breasts being drilled from behind by a STEROID-ENHANCED MAN. He grunts; she moans. Wider reveals that we are watching the action on a wall-mounted VIDEO MONITOR in -- INT. “COLLECTION” ROOM - DAY Richard sits with his pants around his ankles and the emp SPECIMEN CUP in his hand, staring at the screen with a lo of profound despair. Unable to bear another moment, he aims the remote and pre STOP, but the horror show continues. Richard tries anothe button, but the moaning and grunting just get LOUDER. Desperate, he shakes the remote and TWO BATTERIES fall ou rolling across the floor. With his pants still around his ankles, Richard stands an shuffles to the monitor. A LARGE SHEET OF SANITARY PAPER stuck to his ass and CRINKLES loudly. CLICK, he switches off the MONITOR. Silence at last. Then
My eight year old came to work one day...
The ANESTHESIOLOGIST hovers over the camera.

..--to see what I do. You know, “Take Your Daughter to Work Day.” REVERSE, Rachel is looking up from a surgical table as th anesthesiologist rambles on, injecting her with a sedati She said it was the most boring job in the world. All I do all day is put people to sleep. Rachel smiles politely as her eyes drift shut and we -- FADE TO BLACK. UNDER BLACK, HUSHED VOICES speaking in a foreign tongue. Hebrew?

text: A BLURRY HASIDIC MAN in a dark suit standing next to his wife’s bed, talking to her. He wears a hat; she wears a w

observing her exotic neighbors as she wakes up. Rachel gets up on her elbows and looks around to find tha all the women in the surrounding beds have been joined by their husbands or partners. She calls to a passing NURSE.
(groggy, weak) Excuse me...(louder) Ma’am? Nurse? The nurse finally hears Rachel and goes to her. Where’s my husband?
Your birth partner hasn’t joined you? Rachel shakes her head. The nurse refers to her paperwork
He’s my husband.
Excuse me?
My birth partner... he’s... (mispronouncing as my husband. “Grimes” ) Not that that matters, it’s Mr. Grimes? just...
(correcting “Grimes” ) Grimes. Yes. Richard Grimes. Rachel notices a flicker of concern on the nurse’s face she reads something on the clipboard.
You’1ll need to speak to a Doctor. (walking away) Let me go find someone.
Is something wrong?
It’‘ll be just a moment.

(mounting panic) Why can’t you just tell me? Hello! The nurse disappears. Fuck! Rachel’s eyes land on her Hasidic neighbors who regard he with flat stares. She smiles, but their faces remain expressionless.
There wasn’t any sperm. Rachel turns to discover a FEMALE DOCTOR at the foot of her bed. Pause.
(puzzled) Excuse me...
Your husband didn’t have any sperm.
Wait. You mean, like... he couldn’t... do it?

No. He produced. And there was semen, but no sperm. (off Rachel's bewilderment) Dr. Dordick will have to give you the details. The doctor leaves and Rachel discovers Richard across the room looking at her with a defeated smile.
DR. DORDICK (60s), silver-haired and handsome in his scru stands at Rachel’s bed side and speaks to our beleaguered couple while drawing a diagram of the male reproductive system on a file folder.

Think of it like a soda machine. Either one of you ever work in a movie theater? The seltzer comes from one place. (pointing with his pen) The syrup comes from someplace else. Together they make Mountain Dew or Diet Coke or what have you. But if the pipe gets... clogged... (draws an X) .+-you don’t get Mountain Dew. You just get... seltzer. Richard is probably blocked.
Mentally? Like psychosomatic?
No. Not mentally. Physically. Like what he’s just been talking about with the soda machine.
Right. Sorry.

I just got off the phone with a buddy of mine. A urologist. Joel Fisher. He’s an expert on this. He’s writing a book about it. Dordick pulls out a XEROXED ARTICLE from New York Magazin and hands it to Richard. The title is: Male Menopause
Oh, my god. That’s so depressing.

Don’t be depressed, Rich. Based on everything that I told him, he’s confident that you’ve got sperm in there. The trick is getting it out. Now, there’s a procedure for it. And Fisher is definitely the man for the job. It’s called... (pronounced “tessy”) TESE. Testicular sperm extraction.  10 Dordick hands Richard an information sheet on the procedu
(under his breath) Oh, my god.
It’s not as bad as it sounds.
You know he only has one testicle, right? Richard looks at Rachel, incredulous. What? He needs to know.
I realize that. (sighs, then to Dordick.) I only have one testicle.

I saw the note in your file and I filled Fisher in. He doesn’t anticipate a problem. (pointing with his pen) What he’1l do is avoid the vas deferens and go right to the source by doing a testicular biopsy.
Like for cancer?
No, Rachel. Not cancer. I don’t have cancer. I have blocked sperm!
Sorry. He said biopsy.

The thing is if we do TESSE, we’ll have to follow up, with ICSE (pronounced “Icksy”) Intra-Cytoplasmic Sperm Injection. (handing Richard another sheet) It’s an additional expense, but there’s no way around it. The good news is Fisher is available and happens to be in the city today. The bad news is... he‘1l need a check for ten thousand dollars. I know it’s short notice.  11
Not a problem.
It’s not? Richard shakes his head. Dordick prepares to leave.
Take a minute to talk things over and once you're ready, I'll give Fisher a call while Moira helps Richard get suited up and we'll be off to the races.
Richard and Rachel walk down the hall following MOIRA. Rachel pushes her IV pole.
(hushed, but intense) Richard. We don’t have ten thousand dollars.
I’m gonna call Charlie. Rachel slows to a halt. Richard stops, too.
We said we weren’t going to tell anybody.

I know... But what’re we supposed to do, Rache? Eleven of your eggs are sitting in there waiting to be inseminated and we don’t have anything to inseminate them with. Rachel watches with envy as ANOTHER COUPLE, finished with their procedure, walk arm-in-arm toward the exit. If I don’t call him we're screwed. The cycle will be a bust, we’ll have blown through a big chunk our baby budget and you’ll have gone through all this for nothing.

Richard, now wearing a parka over a HOSPITAL GOWN, paces back and forth on the sidewalk, talking on his cellphone.  12 Rachel stands in the vestibule watching him through the glass door. After a few moments, Richard hangs up and heads inside, looking upbeat.
He’s on his way with a check.
He is?
Yep. They walk to the elevator.
Did Cynthia say anything?
What? No. Of course not.
She's so judgmental.
No, she’s not. The elevator arrives. Rachel’s Hasidic neighbors exit, an our couple steps in.
Yes, she is, Richard. She was even weird when we were doing IUIs.
You're being paranoid. The doors close. INT. CHARLIE’S BEDROOM/BATHROOM - DAY CYNTHIA (50s) with messy morning hair stares at someone o screen with her jaw dropped wide open.
They're doing it again?! Reverse shows CHARLIE (50s) at the sink as he turns off t faucet and drags a towel over his wet face.

No. This is something totally different. New doctor. Very high tech with... egg harvesting... and hatching. And something called “Icksee.” Have you seen my pants?  13 Charlie slips past Cynthia, enters the adjoining bedroom starts sifting through strewn clothes.
I thought they were done with all that and they were trying to adopt.
Yeah. They are. They’re still doing that. But after that thing with that girl, they’re trying a “by any means necessary” approach. Doing both at once.
Oh, my god. They’re like compulsive gamblers! Charlie finds his pants, steps into them.

Anyway, it’s really technical and hard to keep track of. But there’s a problem with Richard’s sperm and he needs to borrow ten thousand dollars. Charlie zips his pants and exits. Cynthia runs after him into -- THE HALLWAY --—
You're not going to give it to him?
Of course I am. He’1ll pay me back. Charlie arrives at the STAIRS and heads down. Cynthia follows.

Charlie, if you love Richard and Rachel, do not give them the money. They don’t need money. They need help. Giving them money is just... enabling them. Charlie shoots her a skeptical look as he enters -- THE LIVING ROOM. Cynthia is a few steps behind him.
To what?  14

To pursue this... fantasy of fertility when it’s pretty clear that it’s consuming them -- emotionally and economically. They're strung out. Their marriage is a wreck. They’re always fighting. They’re like fertility junkies.
That’s nuts.

Honey. They’ve been doing this for years. They need to stop. They need to move on. They need an intervention. GIRL’S VOICE (0.S.) Mom? Cynthia and Charlie turn to see their daughter, CHARLOTTE holding A PHONE.

Sadie’s on the phone. She doesn’t sound good. Charlotte looks back and forth between her parents, neith of whom responds so she drops the phone on the couch and leaves. Cynthia and Charlie look at each other. Then, OUT OF THE RECEIVER, a faint voice --
Mom?
(picking up) Hi, honey.
I need to get going. He pulls on a sweater. Cynthia follows him as he makes hi way to the front door where he grabs his coat and exits.
SADIE BARRETT (25) stands outside a dormitory, shivering smoking as she talks on her cellphone. She’s wearing a th oversized sweater and pajama bottoms.
(to Charlie) I really want you to think about what you're doing.  15
Mom? What’s going on?
Cynthia watches from the doorway as Charlie crunches acro the gravel driveway and -- VEEP! VEEP! -- unlocks their Mercedes Station Wagon.
Nothing. We’re just. Charlie’s going into the city and -- Before he gets in the car, Charlie calls out to Cynthia.
I'll pick up some stuff from Russ and Daughter’s. You want salmon?
(covering the phone) Charlotte! You want salmon?
What?
(louder) Dad’s going into Manhattan. You want Russ and Daughters?
Sadie struggles to hear, but she can only make out MUFFLE SOUNDS. Several students trudge by with backpacks. INTERC
Mom?
(to Charlie) A bialy. An everything bagel. And a quarter pound of Wild Nova. (to Sadie) Sorry, honey. Is everything okay?
Uhh... not really.
What’s wrong? Sadie takes a deep drag on her cigarette. Are you smoking?  16
(mouth full of smoke) No. I quit. I told you. (exhales away from phone) I just have a cold. And I’m standing outside and it’s freezing. She drops her cigarette and steps on it.
Where?
Tivoli. School.
Right. Okay. I was just checking. You sound funny. A pause as Sadie summons her courage.
I need to get out of here.
For the Holidays?
No. Before the holidays. And after. (tense pause) I need to leave here for a while.
You just got back there!
I know. I don’t think it was such a good idea.
What do you mean? It was a great idea. You'll finally graduate.
I’m not doing well.
Are you failing?
No. God, mom. Emotionally, not academically. You are so achievement oriented.  17
Finishing college at 25 isn’t exactly an achievement, Sadie. It’s damage control. Sadie’s eyes well up. Cynthia grimaces, regretting her choice of words. I’m sorry. I shouldn’t have said that.
It’s what you think.
No, it’s not. I just... want you to find something that you love doing that gives you a sense of purpose and meaning to your life.
I found it. Remember? Cynthia tries to think of what Sadie is referring to. Writing...

Of course. Yes. And you're really good at it, honey. But if you want to be a writer-writer, a professional, you have to be very driven and disciplined. And if it’s giving you this much trouble in college, what's going to happen in the real world when you need to pay your rent at the same time? Sadie shakes her head.

I’m not failing, Mom. I did a lot of good work at the beginning of the semester that I’m really proud of. It’s just... I’m a little stuck right now and I’m not gonna to be ready to hand in my portfolio in Writing Workshop which counts for like eighty percent of our grade. But the good news is my professor really believes in me and she’s willing to give me an incomplete which is great because... Sadie trails off.
Sadie? What?  Pause. 18
Nothing. I guess I’m waiting for you to tell me that in “real life” there’s no such thing as an incomplete.
Honey, why don’t you just come home, and we can talk about this in person.
I can’t come home, mom.
Why not?
(hesitant) Because... I want to be in the city.
Oh, god, Sadie, how’re you going to do that?
I'll work. I'll waitress. It’s not gonna cost you a penny. I promise. Uncle Richard and Aunt Rachel said I could stay at their place whenever I want.
Honey, Richard and Rachel have a lot on their plate. Trust me. They’re not in a position to take care of anyone but themselves right now.

Richard and Rachel, the last remaining patients, lie in adjacent beds. He clutches an ice pack to his crotch, she a heating pad against her lower abdomen. MELANCHOLY LOW-FI PIANO MUSIC FADES IN as the CAMERA SLOW PULLS AWAY from our reproductively challenged couple.
(singing) Nobody wants a broken toy.... The song transports us to --  19

A GIRL (10), holding a DOC McSTUFFINS’ KARAOKE MICROPHONE sings a song from the show while her YOUNGER SISTER does strange interpretive dance. A REVERSE shows Richard and Rachel watching with polite ambivalence. They sit with other MIDDLE-AGED DINNER GUESTS who form a captive, but charmed, audience. The song ends. The guests applaud. The children beam. CAROLINE (45), the hostess (and mother of the girls), tri to move things along --
Okay, you guys. Say good night to everyone.
Good night! A chorus of “Good night!” from the table as a BABY-SITTER herds the kids off to bed.

The remaining guests lounge with wine and dessert. We drift through the room, catching bits of conversation. We hear a party-goer, DAVID, talk about alternate side parking rules. In a corner, we find Richard talking to Caroline’s husband BRAD. Rachel is nearby.

It’s just party people drinking themselves sick on the weekends. I can barely walk the dogs at night. I just don’t want to find myself at fifty sitting at a block association meeting trying to prevent a new bar from opening.
Honey, we're not going to turn fifty on East 6th Street.
I’m forty-seven!
Caroline removes a bottle of wine from the fridge as Rach enters, carrying dishes. We hear voices from the other ro
You guys seem great.  20
Me and Brad? We haven’t spoken in two days.
What?

For the last forty-eight hours we have not uttered a word to each other. Just then, Brad enters the kitchen with some dessert plat That's how we fight. Right, honey? No words. Brad looks at Rachel, shrugs in agreement, deposits dishe on the counter and leaves.
When’s your book coming out?
April.
(opening the wine) That's exciting. I haven’t written jack-shit since Talia was born. The cork comes out and Caroline begins to pour. You have got to try this. I’m obsessed. I drank it all summer.
No, thanks.
Really? It’s Prosecco. You’re not a Prosecco person?
No. I am. I love it. It’s just, I can’t... I’m cycling.
Oh, my god. Soul Cycle? My sister does that and her ass is like two little coconuts. Do you love it?
Oh, no. Not that kind of cycling. (hesitant) It’s... IVF.  21
(covers her mouth) Oh, my god. I am so sorry. What an idiot. She hugs Rachel.
It’s okay.
No, it’s not. I’m such a dope. Wow. I didn’t know you guys were back to doing that. I thought you we're trying to adopt.

No. Yeah. We are. We just figured, while we're waiting, we might as well give this a shot. Ha! That’s a good one, right? Giving IVF a shot. It’s our first time, actually. We did lots of IUIs before, but we never brought out the big guns.
It’ll really increase your chances, though, right?
Yeah. I don’t know. Our numbers aren’t so great.

You should talk to my cousin, Erin. She did IVF to get her kids and her doctors told her she shouldn’t even bother. Her chances were like one percent or something. And she got pregnant twice. In her forties. With only one ovary. Rachel, rapt, mouths “wow.” I’m sure she’d love to talk to you about it. And her kids are amazing. Caroline pulls a photo of Erin and her two kids off the fridge and hands it to Rachel.
displaying an enlarged microscopic image of what appears to be TWO CIRCLES OF SUDSY SPITTLE.  22 SUPERIMPOSE -—
A WIDER ANGLE reveals that we are in --

Rachel, her feet in stirrups, lies on a table, tipped so her head is lower than her pelvis. LAB TECHNICIANS and NURSES stand at various stations around the room. Dordick in surgical scrubs, points to one of the spittle circles.
That’s a double-A embryo, right there. See the tightly packed cells.... That puppy is raring to go. We’ll transfer both, but I’m putting my money on this guy. (turning to Rachel) You ready?
(not sure) Uh-huh.

(a smile, then to the room--) Alrightie. Here we go, guys. It’s show time. LIGHTS dim. A GIANT SURGICAL LAMP GOES ON. Dordick sits on a stool with wheels and rolls in between Rachel’s legs Your job is to just relax and breathe, okay? Rachel nods, not relaxed at all. Dordick holds out his hand and a nurse supplies him with a SPECULUM.
This might feel a little cold... Just relax... That’s it. MELLOW GUITAR MUSIC begins to play. Do you like The Eagles? Rachel has no idea what he’s talking about until the vocals begin:

Every night... I'm lyin' in bed... Holdin' you close in my dreams... Dordick smiles and raises his eyebrows. Rachel politely smiles back and nods.  23 Dordick holds out a hand and an embryologist gives him a CATHETER. With one eye on Rachel’s cervix and the other o the ultrasound monitor, he speaks softly --
Alright. Let’s get pregnant, shall we? Rachel smiles weakly and watches Dordick mouth the lyrics as he guides the catheter deep into her body.
Oh, oh, oh, oh, sweet darlin’ you get the best of my love...

Rachel holds the collar of her coat closed as she and Ric stand on blustery First Avenue, searching for a cab. Spotting one, Richard raises his arm and a PIECE OF PAPER he’s holding is snatched from his hand by the wind.
Oh, my god! Richard. Richard chases the paper down the sidewalk, awkwardly crouching as he goes. Pedestrians step out of the way and give him looks. Rachel watches with a hand over her mouth

Richard smooths the paper against his thigh and rubs it, trying to remove the dirt and creases. For the first time see that it’s a BLACK & WHITE IMAGE of their embryos. The cab hits a large pot hole, making a jarring dip and b
Ugh. (to the driver) Excuse me? Sir? The PAKISTANI CAB DRIVER conversing in Urdu on his headse doesn’t respond.
(quietly to Rachel) It’s okay.

No, it’s not. I’m trying to implant. Rachel unbuckles her seat-belt and sticks her head throug the opening in the Plexiglass divider. Sir.  24 Startled, the driver yanks out his earbuds. Hi. I’m sorry, but I just had a medical procedure. Gynecological. The driver looks terrified. So if you would slow down and take it easy on the bumps, I’d appreciate it. As soon as Rachel retracts her head from the opening, the cabdriver slides the window shut. WHACK!
BATHROOM TILE being mercilessly scrubbed.

WIDER reveals we are in-- INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - DAY Rachel is on all fours in the bathtub, scrubbing the tile Meanwhile, the dogs follow Richard as he enters the bedroom with an armful of fertility medication. He kicks the lid off a WICKER HAMPER and dumps everything inside.
(yelling) How are we doing?
Good! Richard spots the WATER BOTTLE filled with used syringes and tosses it into the hamper. As of now, no IVF materials are in sight. BACK IN THE BATHROOM -—
Great!
Do you think we should take down the Lisa Yuskavage?
What? No! Richard has wandered into --  25 THE LIVING ROOM, where he stares at something off-screen.

I’m just looking at it from Beth's perspective. We’re used to it, but... If you and I sit next to each other on the couch and Beth sits across from us... Richard takes a seat in the only chair opposite the couch It’s like right in her face.
(entering with a sponge) What is?
The vagina. ANOTHER ANGLE reveals a SEXUALLY EXPLICIT LITHOGRAPH of a nude woman with her legs splayed open. I think we should at least move it. So it’s not so... central.

(thinks for a moment, then --) No. Uh-uh. If our social worker is so uptight that she would actually deny us a child because we have a... vagina on our wall, well then... just... screw everything... Rachel marches back to the kitchen and gets down on all fours.

I mean, just fuck it! (shaking Ajax on the floor) I am so sick of these people judging us and telling us what to do all the time. Between the doctors and the social workers and the support groups, it’s just like, shut the fuck up already and shove it up your fucking asses!
A civilized tableau: Rachel and Richard, nicely dressed a flanked by their dogs, sit on the couch across from BETH (50), a compact social worker. While Rachel pours tea, Be reviews their file.  26

Before Kyra went on maternity leave she walked me through everything, so I'm pretty up-to-date. But nothing can replace talking face-to-face. (receiving her tea) Mmm, thank you. As Beth takes a sip, her eyes land on the lithograph and the VAGINA. She seems hypnotized by it. Richard gives Rachel an “I told you so” look.
She's a good friend of ours. Not the woman in the picture. The artist who made it. She’s our friend. It was a wedding present.
(back to business) So, it looks like you came to adoption after some fertility treatments. Nervous “Uh-huhs and “Yeahs” before an uncomfortable paus
It wasn’t for us. Didn’t feel right. Beth nods sympathetically as she writes something down.
Plus Richard only has one testicle, so... Richard shoots his wife a look. Beth moves things along.
I see that you were matched with a birthmother last winter. Would you mind telling me a little bit about that? Richard and Rachel check in with each other. Richard nods

Okay. Um. We’d been officially waiting for a couple of months and we weren’t getting any calls, which was totally depressing. Kyra told us about Parent Portraits... Beth nods knowingly. «+-SO we decided to give it a try. (MORE )

27 About a week after our page went up, we got a call... INT. RACHEL AND RICHARD’S APARTMENT - FLASHBACK - NIGHT A RINGING PHONE sits on a desk in their home office. Tape to it is a handmade label: BABY PHONE/INCOMING CALLS ONLY Rachel stumbles into the dark room, stubbing her toe en route -- “Oww, Fuck!”

Hello. Yes. Uh-huh. That’s us. She turns on a lamp. With the handset wedged between her shoulder and ear, she pushes aside paperwork to reveal TW PAGES of what appears to be a play taped to the desk. A heading reads: PHONE SCRIPT. No, not at all. “We’re happy you called. It’s the perfect time.” Richard, in boxers, drifts into the room, squinting and scratching his head.
